an5.87:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo ca.
an5.87:1.1.eng: “A senior mendicant with five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.

an5.87:1.3.pli: Sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati. Ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an5.87:1.3.eng: They’re ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an5.87:1.4.pli: bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā;
an5.87:1.4.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.87:1.5.pli: kalyāṇavāco hoti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagaḷāya atthassa viññāpaniyā;
an5.87:1.5.eng: They’re a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.

an5.87:1.6.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī;
an5.87:1.6.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an5.87:1.7.pli: āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an5.87:1.7.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an5.87:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo cā”ti.
an5.87:1.8.eng: A senior mendicant with these five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.”

an5.88:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu bahujanaahitāya paṭipanno hoti bahujanaasukhāya bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an5.88:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a senior mendicant who has five qualities is acting for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of of gods and humans.

an5.88:2.2.eng: They are long standing and have long gone forth.

an5.88:2.3.eng: They’re well-known, famous, with a large following that includes both laypeople and renunciates.

an5.88:2.4.eng: They receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an5.88:2.5.pli: bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā appaṭividdhā;
an5.88:2.5.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.88:2.6.pli: micchādiṭṭhiko hoti viparītadassano, so bahujanaṃ saddhammā vuṭṭhāpetvā asaddhamme patiṭṭhāpeti.
an5.88:2.6.eng: But they have wrong view and distorted perspective. They draw many people away from the true teaching and establish them in false teachings.

an5.88:2.7.pli: Thero bhikkhu rattaññū cirapabbajito itipissa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjanti, ñāto thero bhikkhu yasassī sagahaṭṭhapabbajitānaṃ bahujanaparivāro itipissa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjanti, lābhī thero bhikkhu cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ itipissa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjanti, bahussuto thero bhikkhu sutadharo sutasannicayo itipissa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjanti.
an5.88:2.7.eng: People follow their example, thinking that the senior mendicant is long standing and has long gone forth. Or that they’re well-known, famous, with a large following that includes both laypeople and renunciates. Or that they receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. Or that they’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned.

an5.88:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu bahujanaahitāya paṭipanno hoti bahujanaasukhāya bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an5.88:2.8.eng: A senior mendicant who possesses these five qualities is acting for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.

an5.88:3.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu bahujanahitāya paṭipanno hoti bahujanasukhāya bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an5.88:3.1.eng: A senior mendicant who has five qualities is acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

an5.88:4.2.eng: They are long standing and have long gone forth.

an5.88:4.3.eng: They’re well-known, famous, with a large following, including both laypeople and renunciates.

an5.88:4.4.eng: They receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an5.88:4.5.pli: bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā;
an5.88:4.5.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.88:4.6.pli: sammādiṭṭhiko hoti aviparītadassano, so bahujanaṃ asaddhammā vuṭṭhāpetvā saddhamme patiṭṭhāpeti.
an5.88:4.6.eng: And they have right view and an undistorted perspective. They draw many people away from false teachings and establish them in the true teaching.

an5.88:4.7.pli: Thero bhikkhu rattaññū cirapabbajito itipissa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjanti, ñāto thero bhikkhu yasassī sagahaṭṭhapabbajitānaṃ bahujanaparivāro itipissa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjanti, lābhī thero bhikkhu cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ itipissa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjanti, bahussuto thero bhikkhu sutadharo sutasannicayo itipissa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjanti.
an5.88:4.7.eng: People follow their example, thinking that the senior mendicant is long standing and has long gone forth. Or that they’re well-known, famous, with a large following that includes both laypeople and renunciates. Or that they receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. Or that they’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned.

an5.88:4.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato thero bhikkhu bahujanahitāya paṭipanno hoti bahujanasukhāya bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti.
an5.88:4.8.eng: A senior mendicant who possesses these five qualities is acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”

an5.89:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattanti.
an5.89:1.1.eng: “These five things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.89:1.3.pli: Kammārāmatā, bhassārāmatā, niddārāmatā, saṅgaṇikārāmatā, yathāvimuttaṃ cittaṃ na paccavekkhati—
an5.89:1.3.eng: They relish work, talk, sleep, and company. And they don’t review the extent of their mind’s freedom.

an5.89:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattanti.
an5.89:1.4.eng: These five things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.89:2.1.pli: Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattanti.
an5.89:2.1.eng: These five things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.89:2.3.pli: Na kammārāmatā, na bhassārāmatā, na niddārāmatā, na saṅgaṇikārāmatā, yathāvimuttaṃ cittaṃ paccavekkhati—
an5.89:2.3.eng: They don’t relish work, talk, sleep, and company. And they review the extent of their mind’s freedom.

an5.89:2.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattantī”ti.
an5.89:2.4.eng: These five things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.”

an5.9:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu agāravo appatisso cavati, nappatiṭṭhāti saddhamme.
an5.9:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a disrespectful and irreverent mendicant with five qualities fails, and doesn’t establish themselves in the true teaching.

an5.9:1.3.pli: Assaddho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu agāravo appatisso cavati, nappatiṭṭhāti saddhamme.
an5.9:1.3.eng: A disrespectful and irreverent mendicant who is faithless …

an5.9:1.4.pli: Ahiriko, bhikkhave, bhikkhu agāravo appatisso cavati, nappatiṭṭhāti saddhamme.

an5.9:1.5.pli: Anottappī, bhikkhave, bhikkhu agāravo appatisso cavati, nappatiṭṭhāti saddhamme.

an5.9:1.6.pli: Kusīto, bhikkhave, bhikkhu agāravo appatisso cavati, nappatiṭṭhāti saddhamme.

an5.9:1.7.pli: Duppañño, bhikkhave, bhikkhu agāravo appatisso cavati, nappatiṭṭhāti saddhamme.
an5.9:1.7.eng: witless fails, and doesn’t establish themselves in the true teaching.

an5.9:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu agāravo appatisso cavati, nappatiṭṭhāti saddhamme.
an5.9:1.8.eng: A disrespectful and irreverent mendicant with these five qualities fails, and doesn’t establish themselves in the true teaching.

an5.9:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso na cavati, patiṭṭhāti saddhamme.
an5.9:2.1.eng: A respectful and reverent mendicant with five qualities doesn’t fail, and establishes themselves in the true teaching.

an5.9:2.3.pli: Saddho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso na cavati, patiṭṭhāti saddhamme.
an5.9:2.3.eng: A respectful and reverent mendicant who is faithful …

an5.9:2.4.pli: Hirīmā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso na cavati, patiṭṭhāti saddhamme.

an5.9:2.5.pli: Ottappī, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso na cavati, patiṭṭhāti saddhamme.

an5.9:2.6.pli: Āraddhavīriyo, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso na cavati, patiṭṭhāti saddhamme.

an5.9:2.7.pli: Paññavā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso na cavati, patiṭṭhāti saddhamme.
an5.9:2.7.eng: wise doesn’t fail, and establishes themselves in the true teaching.

an5.9:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso na cavati, patiṭṭhāti saddhamme”ti.
an5.9:2.8.eng: A respectful and reverent mendicant with these five qualities doesn’t fail, and establishes themselves in the true teaching.”

an5.90:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattanti.
an5.90:1.1.eng: “These five things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu bahukicco hoti bahukaraṇīyo viyatto kiṅkaraṇīyesu;
an5.90:1.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant trainee has many duties and responsibilities, and is competent in many tasks.

an5.90:1.4.eng: They neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.90:1.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo dhammo sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattati.
an5.90:1.5.eng: This is the first thing that leads to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu appamattakena kammena divasaṃ atināmeti;
an5.90:2.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant trainee spends too much time doing trivial work.

an5.90:2.2.eng: They neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.90:2.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo dhammo sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattati.
an5.90:2.3.eng: This is the second thing that leads to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu saṃsaṭṭho viharati gahaṭṭhapabbajitehi ananulomikena gihisaṃsaggena;
an5.90:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant trainee mixes closely with laypeople and renunciates, socializing inappropriately like a layperson.

an5.90:3.2.eng: They neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.90:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo dhammo sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattati.
an5.90:3.3.eng: This is the third thing that leads to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu akālena gāmaṃ pavisati, atidivā paṭikkamati;
an5.90:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant trainee enters the town at the wrong time, and returns too late in the day.

an5.90:4.2.eng: They neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.90:4.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho dhammo sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattati.
an5.90:4.3.eng: This is the fourth thing that leads to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu yāyaṃ kathā ābhisallekhikā cetovivaraṇasappāyā, seyyathidaṃ—
an5.90:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant trainee doesn’t get to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart, when they want, without trouble or difficulty. That is,

an5.90:5.2.pli: appicchakathā santuṭṭhikathā pavivekakathā asaṃsaggakathā vīriyārambhakathā sīlakathā samādhikathā paññākathā vimuttikathā vimuttiñāṇadassanakathā, evarūpiyā kathāya na nikāmalābhī hoti na akicchalābhī na akasiralābhī;
an5.90:5.2.eng: talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.90:5.3.eng: They neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.90:5.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamo dhammo sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattati.
an5.90:5.4.eng: This is the fifth thing that leads to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:5.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattanti.
an5.90:5.5.eng: These five things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:6.1.pli: Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattanti.
an5.90:6.1.eng: These five things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:6.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu na bahukicco hoti na bahukaraṇīyo viyatto kiṅkaraṇīyesu;
an5.90:6.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant trainee doesn’t have many duties and responsibilities, even though they are competent in many tasks.

an5.90:6.4.pli: na riñcati paṭisallānaṃ, anuyuñjati ajjhattaṃ cetosamathaṃ.
an5.90:6.4.eng: They don’t neglect retreat, and are committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.90:6.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo dhammo sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattati.
an5.90:6.5.eng: This is the first thing that doesn’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu na appamattakena kammena divasaṃ atināmeti;
an5.90:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant trainee doesn’t waste their day doing trivial work.

an5.90:7.2.pli: na riñcati paṭisallānaṃ, anuyuñjati ajjhattaṃ cetosamathaṃ.
an5.90:7.2.eng: They don’t neglect retreat, and are committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.90:7.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo dhammo sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattati.
an5.90:7.3.eng: This is the second thing that doesn’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu asaṃsaṭṭho viharati gahaṭṭhapabbajitehi ananulomikena gihisaṃsaggena;
an5.90:8.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant trainee doesn’t mix closely with laypeople and renunciates, socializing inappropriately like a layperson.

an5.90:8.2.pli: na riñcati paṭisallānaṃ, anuyuñjati ajjhattaṃ cetosamathaṃ.
an5.90:8.2.eng: They don’t neglect retreat, and are committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.90:8.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo dhammo sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattati.
an5.90:8.3.eng: This is the third thing that doesn’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu na atikālena gāmaṃ pavisati, nātidivā paṭikkamati;
an5.90:9.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant trainee doesn’t enter the village too early or return too late in the day.

an5.90:9.2.pli: na riñcati paṭisallānaṃ, anuyuñjati ajjhattaṃ cetosamathaṃ.
an5.90:9.2.eng: They don’t neglect retreat, and are committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.90:9.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho dhammo sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattati.
an5.90:9.3.eng: This is the fourth thing that doesn’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu yāyaṃ kathā ābhisallekhikā cetovivaraṇasappāyā, seyyathidaṃ—
an5.90:10.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant trainee gets to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart, when they want, without trouble or difficulty. That is,

an5.90:10.2.pli: appicchakathā santuṭṭhikathā pavivekakathā asaṃsaggakathā vīriyārambhakathā sīlakathā samādhikathā paññākathā vimuttikathā vimuttiñāṇadassanakathā, evarūpiyā kathāya nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī;
an5.90:10.2.eng: talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.90:10.3.pli: na riñcati paṭisallānaṃ, anuyuñjati ajjhattaṃ cetosamathaṃ.
an5.90:10.3.eng: They don’t neglect retreat, and are committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.90:10.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamo dhammo sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattati.
an5.90:10.4.eng: This is the fifth thing that doesn’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an5.90:10.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattantī”ti.
an5.90:10.5.eng: These five things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.”

an5.91:1.3.eng: Accomplishment in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

an5.92:1.3.eng: Accomplishment in ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.93:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are five ways of declaring enlightenment.

an5.93:1.3.eng: One declares enlightenment out of stupidity and folly.

an5.93:1.4.eng: Or because of corrupt wishes, being of wishful temperament.

an5.93:1.5.eng: Or because of madness and mental disorder.

an5.93:1.8.eng: These are the five ways of declaring enlightenment.”

an5.94:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five ways of living comfortably.

an5.94:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
an5.94:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an5.94:1.4.pli: vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ … tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ … catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
an5.94:1.4.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption …

an5.94:1.5.pli: āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an5.94:1.5.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an5.94:1.6.eng: These are the five ways of living comfortably.”

an5.95:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu nacirasseva akuppaṃ paṭivijjhati.
an5.95:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant who has five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.

an5.95:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu atthapaṭisambhidāpatto hoti, dhammapaṭisambhidāpatto hoti, niruttipaṭisambhidāpatto hoti, paṭibhānapaṭisambhidāpatto hoti, yathāvimuttaṃ cittaṃ paccavekkhati.
an5.95:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant has attained the textual analysis of meaning, text, definition, and eloquence, and they review the extent of their mind’s freedom.

an5.95:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu nacirasseva akuppaṃ paṭivijjhatī”ti.
an5.95:1.4.eng: A mendicant who has these five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.”

an5.96:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu ānāpānassatiṃ āsevanto nacirasseva akuppaṃ paṭivijjhati.
an5.96:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant cultivating mindfulness of breathing who has five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.

an5.96:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu appaṭṭho hoti appakicco subharo susantoso jīvitaparikkhāresu;
an5.96:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant has few obligations and duties, and is unburdensome and contented with life’s necessities.

an5.96:1.4.eng: They eat little, not devoted to filling their stomach.

an5.96:1.5.eng: They are rarely drowsy, and are dedicated to wakefulness.

an5.96:1.6.pli: bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā;
an5.96:1.6.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.96:1.7.eng: They review the extent of their mind’s freedom.

an5.96:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu ānāpānassatiṃ āsevanto nacirasseva akuppaṃ paṭivijjhatī”ti.
an5.96:1.8.eng: A mendicant cultivating mindfulness of breathing who has these five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.”

an5.97:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu ānāpānassatiṃ bhāvento nacirasseva akuppaṃ paṭivijjhati.
an5.97:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant developing mindfulness of breathing who has five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.

an5.97:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu appaṭṭho hoti appakicco subharo susantoso jīvitaparikkhāresu;
an5.97:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant has few concerns and duties, and is unburdensome and contented with life’s necessities.

an5.97:1.4.eng: They eat little, not devoted to filling their stomach.

an5.97:1.5.eng: They are rarely drowsy, and are dedicated to wakefulness.

an5.97:1.6.eng: They get to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart, when they want, without trouble or difficulty. That is,

an5.97:1.7.pli: appicchakathā …pe… vimuttiñāṇadassanakathā, evarūpiyā kathāya nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī;
an5.97:1.7.eng: talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, keeping your distance, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.97:1.8.eng: They review the extent of their mind’s freedom.

an5.97:1.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu ānāpānassatiṃ bhāvento nacirasseva akuppaṃ paṭivijjhatī”ti.
an5.97:1.9.eng: A mendicant developing mindfulness of breathing who has these five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.”

an5.98:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu ānāpānassatiṃ bahulīkaronto nacirasseva akuppaṃ paṭivijjhati.
an5.98:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant practicing mindfulness of breathing who has five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.

an5.98:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu appaṭṭho hoti appakicco subharo susantoso jīvitaparikkhāresu;
an5.98:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant has few obligations and duties, and is unburdensome and contented with life’s necessities.

an5.98:1.4.eng: They eat little, not devoted to filling their stomach.

an5.98:1.5.eng: They are rarely drowsy, and are dedicated to wakefulness.

an5.98:1.6.eng: They live in the wilderness, in remote lodgings.

an5.98:1.7.eng: They review the extent of their mind’s freedom.

an5.98:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu ānāpānassatiṃ bahulīkaronto nacirasseva akuppaṃ paṭivijjhatī”ti.
an5.98:1.8.eng: A mendicant practicing mindfulness of breathing who has these five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.”

an5.99:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, towards evening the lion, king of beasts, emerges from his den,

an5.99:1.4.pli: samantā catuddisaṃ anuviloketvā tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati;
an5.99:1.4.eng: and roars his lion’s roar three times.

an5.99:1.5.eng: Then he sets out on the hunt.

an5.99:1.6.pli: So hatthissa cepi pahāraṃ deti, sakkaccaññeva pahāraṃ deti, no asakkaccaṃ;
an5.99:1.6.eng: If he strikes an elephant, he does it carefully, not carelessly.

an5.99:1.7.pli: mahiṃsassa cepi pahāraṃ deti, sakkaccaññeva pahāraṃ deti, no asakkaccaṃ;

an5.99:1.8.pli: gavassa cepi pahāraṃ deti, sakkaccaññeva pahāraṃ deti, no asakkaccaṃ;

an5.99:1.9.pli: dīpissa cepi pahāraṃ deti, sakkaccaññeva pahāraṃ deti, no asakkaccaṃ;

an5.99:1.10.pli: khuddakānañcepi pāṇānaṃ pahāraṃ deti antamaso sasabiḷārānampi, sakkaccaññeva pahāraṃ deti, no asakkaccaṃ.
an5.99:1.10.eng: or any smaller creatures—even a hare or a cat—he does it carefully, not carelessly.

an5.99:1.12.eng: Thinking: ‘May I not lose my way.’

an5.99:2.1.pli: Sīhoti kho, bhikkhave, tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
an5.99:2.1.eng: ‘Lion’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

an5.99:2.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tathāgato parisāya dhammaṃ deseti, idamassa hoti sīhanādasmiṃ.
an5.99:2.2.eng: When the Realized One teaches Dhamma to an assembly, this is his lion’s roar.

an5.99:2.3.pli: Bhikkhūnañcepi, bhikkhave, tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti, sakkaccaññeva tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti, no asakkaccaṃ;
an5.99:2.3.eng: When the Realized One teaches the monks …

an5.99:2.4.pli: bhikkhunīnañcepi, bhikkhave, tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti, sakkaccaññeva tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti, no asakkaccaṃ;

an5.99:2.5.pli: upāsakānañcepi, bhikkhave, tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti, sakkaccaññeva tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti, no asakkaccaṃ;

an5.99:2.6.pli: upāsikānañcepi, bhikkhave, tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti, sakkaccaññeva tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti, no asakkaccaṃ;

an5.99:2.7.pli: puthujjanānañcepi, bhikkhave, tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti antamaso annabhāranesādānampi, sakkaccaññeva tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti, no asakkaccaṃ.
an5.99:2.7.eng: or ordinary people—even food-carriers and hunters—he teaches them carefully, not carelessly.

an5.99:2.9.eng: Because the Realized One has respect and reverence for the teaching.”
